precautions: Use virus-free seedlings, control whitefly populations, remove infected plants promptly.
environment: Favored by warm, dry climates and high whitefly populations.
management: Practice crop rotation, use reflective mulches, apply insecticides strategically.
crop_rotation: Avoid rotating with solanaceous crops; use non-hosts like cereals.
pruning: Remove and destroy infected shoots/leaves early.
chemical_control: Use systemic insecticides (e.g., Imidacloprid) to control whiteflies.
irrigation_timing: Morning irrigation helps reduce whitefly activity.
monitoring: Use yellow sticky traps to monitor whitefly activity.
fungicides: Not applicable, since it's a viral disease.
weed_control: Remove alternate hosts of whiteflies like weeds and ornamentals.

precautions: Avoid overhead irrigation, sanitize tools, and avoid field work when foliage is wet.
environment: High humidity and warm temperatures favor disease.
management: Rotate crops, remove plant debris, copper sprays can reduce spread.
crop_rotation: Do not plant tomatoes or peppers for 2 years on the same field.
resistant_varieties: Use resistant or tolerant varieties when available.
pruning: Remove infected lower leaves as disease progresses.
seed_treatment: Hot water treatment and seed disinfectants help reduce seedborne transmission.
irrigation_timing: Drip irrigation is preferred; irrigate early in the day.
fertilization: Avoid excessive nitrogen which promotes succulent growth.
monitoring: Look for small, water-soaked spots on leaves and fruits.
ventilation: Ensure good airflow to reduce leaf wetness duration.
fungicides: Fungicides are not effective; bactericides recommended.
weed_control: Remove nightshade and other Solanaceae weeds.

precautions: Use certified seed, apply protectant fungicides before infection.
environment: Cool, wet, and humid conditions favor disease development.
management: Remove infected plants, avoid overhead irrigation, rotate crops.
crop_rotation: Rotate with non-hosts like legumes or cereals for 2–3 years.
resistant_varieties: Use late blight-resistant hybrids like ‘Mountain Magic’.
pruning: Prune to improve airflow and reduce humidity.
chemical_control: Use fungicides like chlorothalonil or metalaxyl in a preventive program.
seed_treatment: Start with disease-free transplants; not seedborne.
irrigation_timing: Irrigate in the morning to allow foliage to dry.
fertilization: Maintain balanced NPK levels; avoid overwatering.
monitoring: Scout for brown-black lesions with white mold growth under humid conditions.
ventilation: Essential in greenhouses to reduce relative humidity.
fungicides: Use systemic + contact fungicides in rotation.
weed_control: Control volunteer potatoes and tomato plants.

precautions: Avoid overhead irrigation, remove lower infected leaves, space plants properly.
environment: Favors humid, rainy weather with moderate temperatures.
management: Crop rotation, fungicide sprays, debris destruction.
crop_rotation: Rotate with non-hosts like grains or legumes.
pruning: Remove lower leaves when first spots are visible.
chemical_control: Use fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb.
seed_treatment: Use certified seed; seed not the primary source.
irrigation_timing: Water early and use drip irrigation to minimize leaf wetness.
fertilization: Avoid nitrogen overuse; ensure balanced nutrients.
monitoring: Look for small, circular spots with dark margins and tan centers.
ventilation: Ensure spacing for air flow to reduce humidity.
fungicides: Apply protectant fungicides at first sign of disease.

precautions: Avoid water stress and monitor under hot, dry conditions.
environment: Thrives in hot, dry weather with dusty conditions.
management: Use miticides, increase humidity, encourage predators like lady beetles.
crop_rotation: No direct benefit, but break mite cycles if possible.
resistant_varieties: Few known; use vigorous cultivars that withstand stress.
pruning: Remove infested leaves with visible webbing.
chemical_control: Use miticides like abamectin or spiromesifen.
irrigation_timing: Adequate irrigation reduces stress and mite outbreaks.
fertilization: Avoid excess nitrogen which boosts mite reproduction.
monitoring: Inspect undersides of leaves for stippling and webbing.
ventilation: Improve airflow to reduce dust and dryness.
weed_control: Eliminate weeds which serve as alternate mite hosts.

precautions: Avoid overhead irrigation, use fungicides, remove infected leaves.

management: Rotate crops, use drip irrigation, fungicide protection.
